ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Developed an intermediate use of the Spanish language. Including the tenses of past preterite, past imperfect, past perfect, present perfect, future simple, and present subjunctive. Also vocabulary surrounding household items, climate, technology, and the workforce among others.
I greatly improved my Spanish speaking, writing, and listening skills.
I continued my basic spanish education
I developed an enhanced knowledge for the spanish language and culture.
How to study correctly including memorization of vocabulary, proper grammar uses, and more.
I learned many grammatical constructions from my textbook and a bit about pronunciation in class.
I advanced my knowledge of Spanish and improved my conversational abilities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: active participation required and therefore a more efficient method of learning. 
Weaknesses: A lot of information to be learned in a short amount of time, a very fast-paced learning environment.

The cultural projects should not need to be memorized. You should not be able to read a pre-typed script, but why should students be forced to spend hours memorizing a presentations worth 1% 3 times per semester? I would recommend allowing notecards in the future.

Weakness: the class varies significantly depending on your professor for your section
Strength: it is a nice continuation of Span I and you learn a lot of concepts and tenses.
Professor Santos could help teach us more material instead of expecting us to teach her like she would say.

The course is certainly rigorous, but that helped me greatly to learn the language.  I had taken language in high school but I hadn't learned this quickly before.  The combination of speaking and writing was helpful.  I think perhaps there could be more of an emphasis on spoken exams.

The course seemed to rush through the material without making sure the student understood each concept in the textbook. Additionally, the material students were responsible for was not covered during class and the activities of class rarely aligned with assessments.

The course is demanding and fast paced, but I felt like there were no weaknesses to this course. I believe that Professor Santos is an amazing professor and I significantly improved my Spanish fluency in this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded "grabaciones" were quite effective in place of some presentations. There was a solid mix of live zoom assignments and class participation with at home virtual assignments.
I liked doing activities in breakout rooms.

I liked the 2 days asynchronous and 3 days synchronous schedule. However, the professor would mainly just put us in breakout rooms for the majority of the class which was not the most productive use of our synchronous days.
Discussions on zoom do not go as planned ninety percent of the time, so bringing classes back to in person would be beneficial.
Virtual lectures worked well.
I think more practice and explanations of the textbook concepts we were responsible for would be very benficial, and not stopping supersite near the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course because I find learning another language both intellectually challenging but also intriguing to see the different structures that languages use.
Yes. Spanish is an incredibly useful language and the Yale curriculum is challenging but engaging.

I would not recommend this course if you are taking it with professor Santos. While she can be nice, I think she (understandably) struggled to teach this course over zoom. Moreover, it was felt that she expected you to learn the information all on your own and provided no review or general summary of concepts. She simply put students in breakouts room to do work which often just felt like a waste of time. She also spoke in english often to clarify logistics, which meant that spanish was barely spoken in class. I felt like I did not learn as much as I could have in this course.
I would but not with Professor Santos. She was unpredictable and hard to understand what she wanted from us as students.
Yes, if this student wanted to learn Spanish and was serious about the language, I would recommend it.

I would not recommend this course to another student because I think that it felt very hectic and confusing with minimal practice speaking and comprehending the language in class. Additionally, I think students are expected to know more information than they learned from L1 because many students placed into this class or had some background in Spanish before taking L1, so if someone has not taken the language before, I would recommend they not begin.
Absolutely. I learned more spanish over these last two semesters than the previous 7 or so years of Spanish combined.
Yes

I would highly recommend Professor Santos' SPAN 120 course. Professor Santos closely worked with her students all semester. She is understanding and makes coming to class fun! I was delighted to have her class for this past semester, and I hope she can teach me in the future!
